current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text:
Recognizing the 200th anniversary of the
		  Battle of Lake Erie.

sponsor.#tail:
submitted the
			 following resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text:
recognizes the
			 200th anniversary of the Battle of Lake Erie;

remembers with
			 great pride this significant victory in the

commends the city
			 of Erie, Pennsylvania, and the Perry 200 Commemoration Commission for their
			 efforts to ensure the appropriate recognition of this historic event;
			 and

expresses its
			 deepest gratitude to all the sailors and marines who gave their lives in
			 honorable service to the United States of America on the Great Lake of Erie 200
			 years ago.

Whereas the American forces, under the command of
			 28-year-old Rhode Island native Oliver Hazard Perry, were tasked to subdue the
			 enemy fleet on the lake and sever its vital supply lines to the northwestern
			 front;

Whereas the United States fleet met its adversaries a
			 short distance from Put-in-Bay, Ohio, on September 10, 1813;

quote.#text:
We have met the enemy, and they are ours—two
			 ships, two brigs one schooner & one sloop.

text.#text:
Whereas to communicate the conclusion of the engagement to
			 Major General William Henry Harrison, Commodore Perry provided the historic and
			 succinct battle summary:

Whereas the victory solidified American control of Lake
			 Erie for the duration of the conflict, enabling United States forces to retake
			 Detroit and win further battles in the Old Northwest and the Niagara
			 Valley;

Whereas the State of Pennsylvania to this day maintains
			 the U.S. Brig Niagara as its State ship;

quote.#tail:
, is preserved in the United States Naval Academy
			 Museum in Annapolis, Maryland; and

text.#text: Whereas the battle flag of Commodore Perry,

Whereas the battle is immortalized in the United States
			 Senate by the masterpiece painted by William Henry Powell in 1873: Now,
			 therefore, be it
